body:
GO ahead. Ask Antoinette Balzano. Ask her why Totonno’s , the pizzeria in Coney Island, matters.
 
“Here’s what we mean to the city,” she said the other day, her voice rising with emotion. Ms. Balzano, one of the heirs to the pizzeria, pointed at a black-and-white photograph, leaning on a tabletop, showing a
title: Fighting to Save the Flavor of New York

body:
Its black glass exterior soars high above Fifth Avenue, and its gold-tipped revolving doors have spun the likes of Bruce Willis and Anne Hathaway into its waterfall-splashed atrium.
 
But on Election Day, Trump Tower earned a different sort of distinction: a tiny island of Romneyville amid Manhattan’s deep, blue-state sea. The tower
title: On Island Largely Blue, An Exception: Trump Tower

author: Marv Albert is the lead N.B.A. announcer for TNT.
body:
The Nets have come to Brooklyn, where I grew up. And even after nearly 50 years of calling basketball games, I can’t wait.
 
Around the city, people keep asking me about the Nets — at a rate that I never thought possible. Fanatics from New Jersey used to be the only people who wanted to chat me up about the Nets. Sometimes,
title: ESSAY; Back Home in Brooklyn And Greeting a New Resident

body:
New York City public schools will remain closed through the rest of the week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday, creating an enormous scheduling headache for harried parents.
 
The mayor said he expected almost all schools to reopen on Monday. He acknowledged it was an “inconvenience for parents” for children to miss a
title: Storm Closes City Schools for a Week, the System’s Longest Suspension in Decades

author: Marv Albert, the lead N.B.A. announcer for TNT, will call the Knicks-Nets game with Steve Kerr on Thursday at 7 p.m.
body:
The Nets have come to Brooklyn, where I grew up. And even after nearly 50 years of calling basketball games, I can’t wait.
 
But when I call their first regular-season game at Barclays Center, on Thursday night against the Knicks , I will not be curious about whether the move from New Jersey will go well. It will. I will want to know
title: Back Home in Brooklyn, Marv Albert Welcomes a New Resident

body:
‘JACKIE AND ME’

 
Many feisty preteen boys would rather throw a punch than turn the other cheek. In the play “Jackie and Me,” Joey Stoshack tries both, ultimately finding himself in a fight whose implications go well beyond his schoolyard. Joey, it turns out, has an unusual talent: When he holds a baseball
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Around Town Museums and Sites 'In Pursuit of a Vision' (Wednesday through Nov. 17) For two centuries, the American Antiquarian Society in Worcester, Mass., has been collecting early Americana, imprints and manuscripts. A selection of items from its library will be on display at the Grolier Club, including a copy of a book printed by Benjamin
title: Spare Times

author: Dan Klores is a Peabody Award-winning filmmaker and playwright. His first film was ''The Boys of Second Street Park.''
body: Before I was to play in the public school gym or the local Y, and at about the same time I had my first crush on Annette, the Mouseketeer , I used to gaze at the tall, gray steel backboard with the orange rim. For my first shot, I used a dodgeball. I didn't have, let alone own, a real ball, a Voit. My sporting life in Brooklyn had actually begun
title: ESSAY; The Brooklyn Game Had Its Own Beat

body: The houses in Neponsit and Belle Harbor, Queens , out past the last stop on the A train on the Rockaway Peninsula, are not what you picture when you think of New York City. Sandwiched between Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, the homes have cedar shingles or vinyl siding, wraparound porches or, occasionally, a modern, boxy structure that stands
title: THE APPRAISAL; Seasonal Parking Bans Please Rockaways Residents but Irk Visitors

body: GEORGE R. BROADHEAD, a retired newspaper executive and Marine Corps veteran, has lived in Beverly Hills and Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Greenwich, Conn., among many other places. The place he is choosing to spend his retirement, though, is the place where he grew up: Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn .That doesn't mean Mr. Broadhead, who is the president
title: LIVING IN | GERRITSEN BEACH, BROOKLYN; The Art of Hiding in Plain Sight

body: For much of the past century, Brooklyn was the Rodney Dangerfield of boroughs, known for its blue-collar style, for its funny accent and, of course, for getting no respect. Then came the brownstone homesteaders and the bohemian pioneers. They turned lunch-bucket warrens in Park Slope, Dumbo and Williamsburg into glamorous destinations, drawing a
title: As Brooklyn Gentrifies, Some Neighborhoods Are Being Left Behind

body: FIFTEEN miles from Midtown Manhattan, at the end of a cul-de-sac in Brooklyn, a gate opens onto a resortlike compound with a two-and-a-half-story home that comes with an infinity pool, a hot tub, a bar and a 170-foot-wide stretch of private oceanfront. Who knew that South Brooklyn could feel so much like South Beach? ''Nobody can imagine that this
title: EXCLUSIVE | MANHATTAN BEACH, BROOKLYN; Where Brooklyn Meets Florida

body: Suddenly, Charles Barron has regained the ability to shock. The New York political world had long ago become accustomed to the incendiary words of Mr. Barron, a confrontational onetime Black Panther turned three-term City Councilman. His more outrageous remarks over the years, from calling Thomas Jefferson a pedophile to likening Gaza to a
title: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Provocateur Surges in a Primary Race for Congress

body: To the Editor: Re ''This Is How We Ride'' (Sunday Review, May 27): The musician David Byrne writes about the joys of urban cycling and compares New York City with other places around the world, but he doesn't mention a couple of key ingredients that make a city bike-friendly. I am an American living in Berlin, and like many Berliners, I don't own a
title: LETTERS; Bike-Sharing Comes to New York

body: 'ALICE IN WONDERLAND' The adventures Lewis Carroll created for a certain little British girl have a way of playing with your head. As well as the Queen of Hearts' constant orders to cut off that precious part, the story offers disorienting size changes, mind-boggling puns, odd manipulations of time and a psychedelic sensibility that's more 1960s
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: There was no shortage of people who had a problem with Brian J. Weiss. A top official of a company based in southern Florida that marketed dietary and health supplements over the Internet, Mr. Weiss reeled in a fortune billing people for what had been promised as free samples of colon cleansers, red-wine extracts and anti-wrinkle creams, among
title: Man Killed At Hotel Had a Host Of Critics

body: To many Russian and Ukrainian immigrants, the cornucopia in the shops along Brighton Beach Avenue -- pyramids of oranges, heaps of Kirby cucumbers, bushels of tomatoes with their vines still attached and a variety of fish, sausages and pastries -- seems like an exuberant rebuke of the meager produce that was available to them when they lived in the
title: Among City's Soviet Immigrants, An Affinity for Republicans

body: PRICEMAN--Shirley, of Cresskill, NJ, formerly a 30 year resident of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn NY on March 26th at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Eileen and her husband Dr. Terry Schwazwald and Dr. Gerald Priceman and his wife Dr. Marla Robbins-Priceman. Loving grandmother of Dana, Golan and Marissa. Cherished
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PRICEMAN, SHIRLEY

body: Jessica Loren Fox and James Henry Bergman were married Saturday evening at the de Seversky Mansion at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. Joseph P. title: Jessica Fox, James Bergman

body: 'The Neverending Story' A centaur, a werewolf, a dragon, a giant turtle, two sphinxes, a mammoth spider and enough new mythological species to populate a second Middle-earth: those characters would make many playwrights hesitate before trying to adapt the German author Michael Ende's 1979 novel, ''The Neverending Story.'' Not to mention that the
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: COUNCILMAN LEWIS A. FIDLER peers at the audience in a low-ceilinged room on Coney Island Avenue with the expectant smile of the newly betrothed. He is running for a State Senate seat and has come to the Davidzon Radio studios on a chill winter afternoon to get the endorsement of political luminaries from the densely Russian Jewish communities of
title: Kingmaker of Little Russia
